entry.title: Mexico lawmakers demand president detail wealth after misrepresentation
entry.summary:
MEXICO CITY, May 29 (Reuters) - Mexico's president came under pressure on Friday to fully disclose his financial assets following a Reuters report on Thursday that he had misrepresented the circumstances under which he acquired a property in a lakeside retreat near Mexico City.

"If he appears as the buyer, there's no way he can say it was a donation," said Elizabeth Yanez, a lawmaker from the center-right opposition National Action Party (PAN) and a member of the transparency committee in Mexico's lower house.

Under Mexican law, even if his father gave him the money to purchase it with, he could not declare it as a donation, lawyers said, pointing to articles 7610 and 7620 of the Civil Code of the State of Mexico, the region where Valle de Bravo lies.

"These sorts of excesses, evidence of falsehood in his declaration of assets ... are incredibly serious," said Alejandro Encinas, a left-leaning senator and former Mexico City mayor, calling for all the assets to be properly disclosed.

The storm is centered about 800 miles (1,285 kilometers) southwest of the southern tip of Baja California, Mexico, and is moving northwest at 10 mph (17 kph).

entry.title: New Mexico Lobbying to Be Storage Site for Nuclear Waste
entry.summary:
New Mexico is touting a rural area in the southeastern part of the state as an interim storage site for the country's high-level nuclear waste, according to a letter issued by Gov. Susana Martinez earlier this month.

Martinez also praised southeastern New Mexico residents for being able to "carve out a niche in the nuclear industry."

"Time and time again, the citizens of southeastern New Mexico have impressed me with their hard work ethic and willingness to tackle national problems that many others consider to be unsolvable," Martinez wrote.

Others, however, have reservations about opening New Mexico to radioactive waste.

He also expressed concern that Martinez seems to be focused on just bolstering southeastern New Mexico.

New Mexico is not the only state competing to be the interim dumping ground for nuclear waste.

entry.title: Mexico working hard to prevent new outbreaks of bird flu: official
entry.summary:
MEXICO CITY Mexico is working hard to prevent outbreaks of a bird flu epidemic that has stricken the U.S. poultry and egg industry in recent months, a senior Mexican agriculture ministry official said on Wednesday.

A strain of the bird flu virus spread across Mexico's poultry industry in 2012 and 2013 and led to the death of nearly 20 million birds over two years.

The official added: "This risk is there due to our shared border and the trade on the border ... but all countries that trade with the United States are in danger not just Mexico."

entry.title: Mexico hit by tornado, floods leaving 13 dead
entry.summary:
Mexico City: A tornado ripped into a town in northern Mexico, killing at least 13 people and flattening hundreds of homes in a deadly six-second blast of carnage.

The tornado came as ferocious weather battered swaths of Mexico and the southern United States, where rescuers hunted for 12 people missing in flash floods across Texas and Oklahoma that left three people dead.

entry.title: Ted Turner Ranch in New Mexico Caught in Wolf Debate
entry.summary:
Now, one of his New Mexico ranches is caught in a dispute between the state and federal wildlife officials over the management of the endangered wolves.

New Mexico wildlife officials recently denied the Ladder Ranch's bid to renew its permit for holding wolves in captivity as part of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's wolf reintroduction program.

Environmentalists say the New Mexico Game Commission's decision raises questions about private property rights.

Ranchers said Monday they supported the Martinez administration's position on the wolf program, noting the absence of a recovery plan even though wolves have been on the ground in New Mexico and Arizona since 1998.

entry.title: Movie shot in Mexico City takes on Trotsky's assassination
entry.summary:
MEXICO CITY (AP) - It's a tale of love, betrayal and history's most famous murder by ice pick.

A death sentence from Josef Stalin hanging over his head, Trotsky traveled to Turkey, France and Norway before Mexico agreed to take him in 1937.

He settled in the colonial-bohemian Mexico City neighborhood of Coyoacan, which was home to famed artists Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo - the latter of whom had an affair with Trotsky.

Budgeted at $7.8 million and scheduled to premiere in 2016, it is the first movie about Trotsky and Mercader to be shot in Mexico and Spain.

Officials say the presence of foreign agents in Mexico will speed up the joint inspection process and facilitate the flow of goods and people across borders.

The bill, which was proposed by President Enrique Pena Nieto, was passed earlier by Mexico's Senate.

entry.title: Mexico bans poultry, egg imports from bird flu-hit Iowa
entry.summary:
MEXICO CITY (Reuters) - Mexico, the biggest buyer of U.S. chicken, has halted imports of live birds and eggs from the U.S. state of Iowa due to an outbreak of deadly bird flu there, the Mexican government said on Tuesday.

Mexico and other major countries last month imposed new export restrictions on poultry products from various U.S. states, but the outbreak has since spread to top U.S. egg-producing state Iowa.

entry.title: Low wages, trade deals luring auto plants and jobs to Mexico

DETROIT (AP) - Mexico has become the most attractive place in North America to build new automobile factories, a shift that has siphoned jobs from the U.S. and Canada, yet helped keep car and truck prices in check for consumers.

In the past two years, eight automakers have opened or announced new plants or expansions in Mexico.

A worker in Mexico costs car companies an average of $8 an hour, including wages and benefits.

Audi also sells the Q5 in the U.S., where tariffs on cars built in Mexico were dropped under the North American Free Trade Agreement.

Automakers now have 18 factories in Mexico, many built in the past 10 years.

Reynosa has been one of the most violent cities in Mexico over the past year, racked by turf wars among the Gulf Cartel and the Zetas, two drug gangs fighting for control of border smuggling routes and crime rackets.

entry.summary:
Activists from Mexico, the United States and Canada have filed a request to the U.N. World Heritage Committee to place the Monarch Butterfly Reserve wintering sites on the list of sites considered in danger.

UNESCO designated the 139,000-acre (56,259 hectare) reserve in the mountains west of Mexico City a World Heritage site in 2008.

But the number of butterflies wintering in Mexico has dropped steeply in recent years, leading to worries the migration might end.

BERLIN - The World Trade Organization has found that the U.S. needs to amend rules underpinning "dolphin-safe" tuna labels, upholding a complaint by Mexico in a long-running dispute.

The U.S. revised rules in 2013 following a previous WTO ruling but Mexico returned to the Geneva-based trade body, arguing they still treat Mexican tuna less favorably than fish from elsewhere.

The Puebla state prosecutor's office said Tuesday the attackers apparently boarded the train around Tierra Blanca, Veracruz, before the line turns inland and heads toward the center of Mexico.

entry.title: 1 migrant killed, 1 wounded in attack on train in Mexico

entry.summary: MEXICO CITY - The host of Mexico's top-rated national morning news and commentary radio show is demanding that her station reinstate two investigative reporters who were fired for misusing its image.

entry.title: Pope Francis: Devil is punishing Mexico with violence
entry.summary:
"I think the devil is punishing Mexico with great fury," the 78-year-old Francis told Mexican television in an interview broadcast late on Thursday when discussing the disappearance and apparent massacre of 43 Mexican students last year.

Arguing that the devil was angry with Mexico for its Christian faith, Francis said "everyone had to put their back into resolving" the criminal malaise afflicting the country.

entry.title: Pope Francis: Devil is punishing Mexico with violence
entry.summary: MEXICO CITY - The devil is punishing Mexico with criminal violence, Pope Francis said, just a few weeks after the Mexican government complained that the Pontiff had stigmatized the country as a breeding ground for gangland chaos.

entry.title: Pope Francis predicts papacy will only last 4-5 years
entry.summary:
He said Mexico has had many martyrs because of the religious persecution it has endured, and because of its "privileged" place in the church thanks to the role the beloved Virgin of Guadalupe plays in its popular faith.

"I think that the devil has punished Mexico with a lot of anger," Francis said, referring to the country's problems with violence and drugs.

"I think the devil can't forgive Mexico."

entry.title: Ex-'Survivor' producer found guilty of killing wife

The former TV producer was extradited to Mexico in 2012 when a judge ordered him to remain in the country.

entry.title: Two mummified bodies found on Mexico's highest peak
entry.summary: Two mummified bodies found on Mexico's highest peak appear to be embracing each other and their discovery could put an end to the mystery of climbers who vanished after an avalanche in 1959, officials said.

MEXICO CITY (AP) " Mexican authorities said Tuesday they staged 153 raids over the last year on a train known as "La Bestia" that rolled toward the U.S. border crowded with hundreds of Central American migrants.

Following a big surge in child migrants reaching the U.S. border last year, Mexico's government cracked down on routes commonly used by migrants to travel from Guatemala to the U.S. border.

entry.title: New Mexico students walk out over new tests contested in US
entry.summary:
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M. (AP) - New assessment tests that have angered parents and teachers across the nation prompted walkouts Monday by hundreds of high school students in New Mexico who had been set to take the exams.

New Mexico is among a dozen states debuting the tests this year.

In New Mexico, a few hundred students at Albuquerque High School joined the walkout despite warnings from administrators that they could face discipline.

entry.title: Official: At least 16 dead in Mexico bus-train crash
entry.summary: MONTERREY, Mexico (AP) - A passenger bus and a freight train collided at a grade crossing in northern Mexico, killing at least 16 people and injuring 22, a Mexican official said.

entry.summary:
At least 16 people have been killed and 22 others injured after a bus and a freight train collided at a level crossing in northern Mexico.

entry.title: Mexico police barricaded in station over labour dispute clash with federal agents
